The anger is understandable, and of course people have a right to peacefully protest, but meeting violence with violence makes things worse. We need to have a real dialogue about how we make more progress towards racial equality on a number of fronts.
Riots resulting in looting, destroying property and small businesses are not the answer. Violent responses will only future divide our polarized country.
Recent events like those in Central Park, Brunswick, GA, & Minneapolis are unacceptable. We need to acknowledge when racial disparities & injustices occur, and work together to address them.
Encouraged that today an officer was arrested and charged w/ murder in #GeorgeFloyd case. As I said on Wednesday and again today in Dayton, what happened was outrageous, and justice must be done.

But on days like today, it's important to remember how much the color of our skin still impacts our lives. It determines where we live, the schools we go to, how much we earn, the opportunities we are provided, and - yes - whether our lives matter.

We have a long way to go. 5/5

When these difficult conversations come up, people like to mention how far we've come as a country.

‚ÄúSlavery ended 150 years ago‚Äù
‚ÄúWe passed the Civil Rights Act‚Äù
‚ÄúJim Crow is gone‚Äù
‚ÄúWe elected a black President‚Äù
 
They argue that these somehow mean we are past racism. 4/5

In these images, African Americans see their children, they see their loved ones, they see themselves. Being Black in America means living with the fear that every interaction with law enforcement is a possible life or death situation. 3/5

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt breathe.‚Äù

The final words of Mr. Floyd echo those of Eric Garner and countless African Americans who have had their lives cut short or forever altered by the very people sworn to protect them. These images leave many feeling anger, fear, frustration, and pain. 2/5

George Floyd was murdered by four police officers as he begged for his life because of the color of his skin. Should they have been fired? Yes. Should they be prosecuted? Yes. But this isn‚Äôt a one-off incident. This has been happening since the dawn of our nation. 1/5

Despite English being a second language for many veterans, @DeptVetAffairs still has not provided public-facing communications in their spoken language ‚Äî even in VA facilities where Spanish or Tagalog are primarily spoken.

Individuals who don't speak English as a first language have a harder time accessing the #healthcare they need.

That need is significantly amplified ‚Äî especially among the many veterans or caregivers who primarily speak other languages ‚Äî during emergencies. https://twitter.com/propublica/status/1245478579544231936 QT @propublica Even in normal times, those who don‚Äôt speak English have worse health outcomes for a range of routine procedures and can struggle to gain access to interpreters. 

Those gaps are magnified in times of crisis.

https://www.propublica.org/article/hospitals-have-left-many-covid19-patients-who-dont-speak-english-alone-confused-and-without-proper-care?utm_content=bufferbbb79&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter&utm_campaign=ProPublica+Main+

Justice is within our reach, but to grasp it we need an honest accounting of our past and a compassionate understanding of our present. Where we go next is up to each and every one of us.

We must acknowledge and learn from our past in order to change our present and improve our future. We are called to combat and confront racism wherever it exists, to counter division with unity, and champion the power of love and grace.

The fight for justice and freedom is constant and it is our job to do the hard work to make those values a reality for everyone. Though I will never fully understand the fear and loss that black communities are forced to confront every day, I can and will stand as an ally.

Above all, we want leaders right now who will lead by example, who accept rather than deflect responsibility, who appeal to the best in us rather than encouraging the worst. 

I'm hopeful there is an army of decent Americans who will be turned off by anyone who fails that test.

We support not just the right of Americans to protest peacefully, but the equal justice and respect that our fellow citizens are protesting for. And we don't approve of anyone using or inciting violence, whatever side they say they're on.

But Americans are broadly united. We've come together to fight Covid-19, accepting huge personal sacrifices to keep each other safe. We're law abiding, and believe that the law should protect everyone equally, regardless of race.

Remember that there are leaders in our country trying to pit us against each other to distract us from their failures. There are extremists who openly say they want a war between races, and against the government, and who use moments like this to accelerate it.

I'm not certain of many things, but I know beyond doubt that what happened to George Floyd in Minnesota and to Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia could not happen to me. We must acknowledge and end the racism that allows it to happen to any of our fellow Americans.
